definitions: make something appear unexpectedly or seemingly from nothing through magic or skill
call upon a spirit or deity to appear through ritual or incantation
earnestly entreat or implore someone to do something urgently
examples: The magician conjured a rabbit from his seemingly empty hat
She could conjure delicious meals from the simplest ingredients available
The witch attempted to conjure spirits from the ancient realm
They gathered at midnight to conjure the ghost of the castle
I conjure you to reconsider your hasty decision immediately
The speaker conjured the audience to act against injustice

definitions: bring together or into contact so that a link is established between things
join or link telecommunication or computer equipment to enable communication or data transfer
establish a relationship or feel an affinity with someone or something
examples: Please connect the two cables using the adapter provided
The new bridge connects the island to the mainland
I cannot connect to the Wi-Fi network without the password
The operator will connect you to the right department shortly
She immediately connected with the audience through her personal stories
The detective connected the suspect to three different crime scenes

definitions: overcome and take control of a place or people by military force
successfully overcome a problem or weakness through effort and determination
gain the love, admiration, or control of someone through charm or ability
examples: Alexander the Great conquered most of the known ancient world
The Romans conquered Britain in the first century AD
She finally conquered her fear of public speaking through practice
Scientists are working to conquer diseases like cancer and AIDS
The young actor conquered Hollywood with his natural charisma
Her brilliant performance conquered the hearts of millions worldwide

definitions: enlist someone compulsorily into military service through legal requirement or draft
compel someone to join or participate in any organization or activity against their will
examples: The government conscripted all men between eighteen and thirty-five
Many young soldiers were conscripted during the Vietnam War era
The company conscripted employees to work overtime during the holiday rush
Local farmers were conscripted to help build the new railway

definitions: make or declare something sacred through religious ceremony or ritual dedication to deity
dedicate something or oneself solemnly to a particular purpose or service
examples: The bishop will consecrate the new cathedral next Sunday morning
The priest consecrated the bread and wine during the mass
She consecrated her life to helping the poor and disadvantaged
The monument was consecrated to the memory of fallen soldiers

definitions: give permission for something to happen or agreement to do something
agree to receive or undertake something offered or proposed by another
examples: The patient must consent to the surgery before it can proceed
Her parents finally consented to her studying abroad for a year
She consented to marry him after months of courtship
The board consented to the merger with the rival company

definitions: protect something from harm or destruction especially natural resources or wildlife
use resources carefully and sparingly to prevent waste or depletion
examples: We must conserve our forests for future generations to enjoy
The organization works to conserve endangered species around the world
Please conserve water during the drought by taking shorter showers
She conserved her energy for the final sprint of the marathon

definitions: think carefully about something typically before making a decision or judgment
regard someone or something as having a specified quality or being in particular category
take something into account when making a judgment or decision about situation
examples: Please consider all the options before making your final decision
The committee will consider your application at the next meeting
Many people consider her the best actress of her generation
I consider it an honor to work with such talented colleagues
You must consider the weather when planning an outdoor wedding
The judge will consider all evidence before reaching a verdict

definitions: be composed or made up of specified elements or ingredients in combination
have something as the essential feature or main element of nature
examples: The committee consists of twelve members from different departments
A water molecule consists of two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen
Success consists in never giving up despite repeated failures
True happiness consists of appreciating what you already have

definitions: comfort someone at a time of grief or disappointment through sympathy and kindness
alleviate or lessen the grief, sorrow, or disappointment of someone experiencing hardship
examples: She tried to console her friend after the unexpected loss
The coach consoled the team after their heartbreaking defeat
Nothing could console him after his beloved dog passed away
Kind words from strangers helped console the grieving family

definitions: combine a number of things into a single more effective or coherent whole
reinforce or strengthen one's position or power making it more secure
examples: The company plans to consolidate its three offices into one location
They consolidated their debts into a single monthly payment
The new CEO consolidated her power by replacing key executives
The army consolidated its position before advancing further north

definitions: habitually associate with someone typically with the disapproval of others watching
be in agreement or harmony with something in a compatible relationship
examples: The prince was criticized for consorting with notorious criminals
She was seen consorting with known enemies of the state
His actions do not consort with his stated principles
These findings consort well with our earlier research conclusions

definitions: make secret plans jointly to commit an unlawful or harmful act against someone
appear to be working together to bring about a particular result typically negative
examples: They conspired to overthrow the government through violent means
The executives conspired to fix prices across the entire industry
Events conspired to ruin our carefully planned vacation completely
The weather and traffic conspired against us reaching on time

definitions: be a part of a whole or be considered as amounting to something
give legal or constitutional form to an institution or establish it formally
examples: These documents constitute the entire agreement between the parties
Women constitute sixty percent of the company's total workforce
The president constituted a special committee to investigate the matter
They constituted themselves as an official advisory board yesterday

definitions: severely restrict the scope, extent, or activity of something or someone
compel or force someone toward a particular course of action against preference
examples: Budget limitations constrain our ability to hire new staff
Regulations constrain how companies can use customer data
He felt constrained to accept the offer despite his reservations
Social expectations constrained her from speaking her true mind

definitions: build or make something physical by putting parts or material together systematically
form an idea, theory, or system by bringing various elements together intellectually
examples: Workers will construct the new bridge over the next two years
The company constructed a factory using environmentally friendly materials
Scientists construct theories based on careful observation and experimentation
Students must construct a logical argument to support their thesis

definitions: seek information or advice from someone with expertise in particular area
refer to a source of information such as a book or database
examples: You should consult a lawyer before signing any legal documents
The patient consulted three specialists about her rare condition
Please consult the manual for detailed installation instructions
Students frequently consult online dictionaries during their language studies

definitions: eat, drink, or ingest food or drink for nourishment or pleasure
use up resources, energy, or time especially in large amounts or completely
completely destroy something especially by fire reducing it to nothing
examples: Americans consume more soft drinks than any other nation worldwide
The guests consumed enormous quantities of food at the wedding
This old car consumes too much fuel for city driving
The project consumed all our resources within just six months
Fire consumed the entire building within a matter of hours
Jealousy consumed him until he could think of nothing else

definitions: make a marriage or relationship complete by having sexual intercourse for first time
complete a transaction or bring something to a successful conclusion through final action
examples: The couple consummated their marriage on their wedding night
Their relationship was never consummated despite years of courtship
They finally consummated the deal after months of difficult negotiations
The merger was consummated with the signing of final documents

definitions: communicate with someone by telephone, letter, email or other means of communication
touch or come into physical touching with another object or surface
examples: Please contact customer service if you experience any problems
I will contact you as soon as I have more information
The two wires must not contact each other or they'll short circuit
Her hand accidentally contacted the hot stove causing a burn

definitions: have or hold something within as constituent parts or enclosed within boundaries
control or restrain oneself or a feeling from being expressed or spreading
examples: This box contains all my childhood photographs and memories
The report contains sensitive information about company finances
She could barely contain her excitement about the promotion
Firefighters worked to contain the blaze before it spread further

definitions: make something impure by exposure to or addition of poisonous or polluting substance
infect or pollute something with harmful or undesirable elements affecting its purity
examples: Industrial waste contaminated the river killing all the fish
The food was contaminated with bacteria causing widespread illness
One bad apple can contaminate the entire batch if not removed
Negative attitudes can contaminate the workplace atmosphere very quickly

definitions: look thoughtfully for a long time at something or think deeply about it
think about whether to do something or consider the possibility of action
examples: She sat contemplating the beautiful sunset over the ocean
Philosophers contemplate the meaning of life and human existence
He is contemplating retirement after thirty years of dedicated service
The board contemplated several options before making their decision

definitions: struggle to surmount a difficulty or compete with others for supremacy
assert something as a position in an argument or state as fact
examples: Three teams are contending for the championship title this year
She had to contend with numerous obstacles throughout her career
The defense contends that their client is innocent of all charges
Scientists contend that climate change poses an immediate threat

definitions: satisfy someone or make them happy with what they have or with situation
examples: She contented herself with a simple meal after the long journey
He was content to watch others play rather than participate

definitions: compete with others in an attempt to win something or establish superiority
oppose an action, decision, or theory as mistaken or challenge its validity
examples: Five candidates will contest the upcoming presidential election
Athletes from fifty countries contested the international championship
The family contested the will claiming it was signed under duress
She contested the parking ticket saying the meter was broken

definitions: persist in an activity or process without stopping for a period of time
begin again after a pause or interruption returning to previous activity or state
examples: The rain continued throughout the night keeping everyone awake
She continued working despite feeling exhausted from the long day
Let's continue this discussion after lunch when everyone returns
The movie will continue after this brief commercial interruption

definitions: mold into a specific shape or follow the natural lines of something
examples: The dress was carefully contoured to fit her body perfectly
The road contours around the mountain following its natural curves

definitions: decrease in size, number, or range by drawing together or shrinking
enter into a formal and legally binding agreement with specified terms and conditions
catch or develop an illness or infectious disease through exposure to pathogens
examples: Metal contracts when it cools and expands when heated
The economy contracted by three percent during the recession
They contracted a builder to renovate their house next spring
The company contracted with suppliers to ensure steady deliveries
He contracted malaria while traveling through tropical regions last year
Several students contracted the flu during the winter outbreak

definitions: deny the truth of a statement by asserting the opposite or different version
be in conflict with or inconsistent with another fact or claim showing incompatibility
examples: The witness contradicted her earlier testimony during cross-examination yesterday
He constantly contradicts everything I say just to be difficult
These findings contradict the conclusions of previous research studies
Your actions contradict your words making it hard to trust you

definitions: differ strikingly from something else when compared or placed in proximity
compare two or more things to show or emphasize their differences clearly
examples: Her cheerful personality contrasts with his serious demeanor significantly
The modern building contrasts sharply with the historic architecture nearby
The professor contrasted democracy with dictatorship in today's lecture
Let me contrast these two approaches to solving the problem

definitions: violate or go against a law, treaty, or other formal agreement deliberately
conflict with or be in opposition to a principle, belief, or established practice
examples: The company's actions contravene international trade regulations and agreements
This policy contravenes the basic human rights protected by law
Such behavior contravenes everything we stand for as an organization
His proposal contravenes established scientific principles and methods

definitions: give money, time, or resources to help achieve or provide something beneficial
help to cause or bring about a result or situation through one's actions
examples: She contributes monthly to several environmental charities and causes
Each team member contributed ideas during the brainstorming session
Poor diet contributes significantly to many health problems today
Several factors contributed to the company's unexpected financial success

definitions: determine the behavior or supervise the running of something with authority
limit, regulate, or keep something under restraint to prevent excess or harm
examples: The pilot controls the aircraft using various instruments and systems
She controls a large corporation with thousands of employees worldwide
The government controls prices to prevent inflation from rising rapidly
You need to control your temper during stressful situations

definitions: come or bring together for a meeting or formal assembly of people
summon or arrange for people to attend a formal meeting or gathering
examples: The board will convene next Monday to discuss the quarterly results
Parliament convenes twice yearly for regular legislative sessions
The chairman convened an emergency meeting of all department heads
The court will convene a special jury for this high-profile case

definitions: come together from different directions to meet at a single point eventually
gradually become similar or come to the same conclusion or result over time
examples: The two rivers converge at the base of the mountain
Protesters converged on the capital from all across the country
Their research findings converge despite using different methodological approaches
Our opinions gradually converged after hours of thoughtful discussion

definitions: engage in conversation or talk with someone in an informal exchange of thoughts
examples: They conversed quietly in the corner during the reception
She loves to converse with people from different cultural backgrounds

definitions: change the form, character, or function of something into something different
change one's religious faith or beliefs to adopt a different religion
examples: They plan to convert the old warehouse into luxury apartments
The software converts digital files into various different formats
He converted to Buddhism after years of spiritual searching
Many people converted to Christianity during the missionary period

definitions: transport or carry something or someone to a place using a vehicle
communicate or make known a message, information, or feeling to someone else
examples: The pipeline conveys oil from the refinery to the port
Trucks convey goods across the country twenty-four hours daily
Her expression conveyed disappointment without saying a single word
Please convey my regards to your family when you see them

definitions: declare someone guilty of a criminal offense by verdict of jury or judge
examples: The jury convicted him of murder after three days of deliberation
She was convicted of fraud and sentenced to five years imprisonment

definitions: cause someone to believe firmly in the truth of something through argument or evidence
persuade someone to do something by presenting compelling reasons or arguments effectively
examples: The lawyer convinced the jury of her client's innocence
Scientific evidence finally convinced him that climate change is real
She convinced her parents to let her study abroad next year
They convinced me to invest in their startup company

definitions: accompany a group of vehicles or ships traveling together for mutual protection
examples: Naval vessels convoyed merchant ships through dangerous waters during wartime
Armed guards will convoy the valuable shipment to its destination

definitions: make a soft murmuring sound like that made by doves or pigeons
speak in a soft gentle loving or amorous way to someone
examples: Doves were cooing softly in the trees outside our window
The baby cooed happily when her mother picked her up
The couple cooed sweet words to each other throughout dinner
She cooed over the adorable puppies at the pet store

definitions: prepare food by heating it in a particular way for consumption
alter or falsify accounts or records to present a misleading picture dishonestly
examples: She loves to cook Italian dishes for her family every Sunday
The meat needs to cook for at least two hours
The accountant was caught cooking the books to hide losses
They cooked up a scheme to avoid paying their taxes

definitions: become or make something less hot by removing heat or exposing to cold
become less angry, excited, or emotional returning to a calmer state gradually
examples: Let the soup cool before serving it to the children
The evening breeze cooled the air after the hot day
Give him time to cool down before discussing the issue again
Their enthusiasm for the project cooled after encountering difficulties

definitions: work jointly with others or together towards the same end or goal
comply with requests or demands showing willingness to help or participate
examples: The two companies will cooperate on developing new technology
All departments must cooperate to make this project successful
The suspect refused to cooperate with the police investigation
Please cooperate with security staff during the screening process

definitions: organize different elements of a complex activity or organization into efficient relationship
match or harmonize attractively or efficiently with something else in appearance or function
examples: She coordinates all the logistics for international conferences worldwide
The manager coordinates the efforts of various teams effectively
Her shoes coordinate perfectly with her handbag and dress
We need to coordinate our schedules to find a meeting time

definitions: receive or suffer something unpleasant such as criticism or punishment inevitably
steal or take something illegally or without permission from someone else
examples: He copped a lot of criticism for his controversial statements
She copped a heavy fine for speeding through the school zone
Someone copped my wallet while I was on the crowded train
The kids copped some candy from the store without paying

definitions: deal successfully with something difficult or manage a challenging situation effectively
examples: She learned to cope with stress through meditation and exercise
The hospital struggled to cope with the influx of patients

definitions: perform a lively dance characterized by kicking and twisting movements from 1920s
examples: They learned to charleston at the vintage dance class downtown
The crowd charlestoned enthusiastically to the jazz band's music
